item.title: Leon Theremin
item.description: Image source: YouTube Instrument: Theremin (1920s) Some movement musicians don’t use computers at all, just electricity and manetism. Leon Theremin created an instrument this way that’s named after him: the Theremin.

item.title: Michel Waisvisz
item.description: Image source: STEIM.org VHS archive Instrument: The Hands (1970s) Michel Waisvisz (said like vice-viss), a Dutch inventor and musician, developed a groundbreaking instrument called The Hands. It was big and clunky by today’s standards, but it was one of the first computer-based gestural controllers.

item.title: Laurie Spiegel
item.description: Image source: YouTube, @jonmerel Instrument: Music Mouse (1980s) Some early movement-based musicians didn’t create new pieces of gear at all, but instead used things that computers already had. Laurie Spiegel created a special computer program called Music Mouse that let people make music by moving their computer mouse–which were brand new at the time.

item.title: Laetitia Sonami
item.description: Image source: Cartier Foundation for Contemporary Art Instrument: Lady’s Glove (1990s) Laetitia Sonami was among the first musicians to start using really small sensors that tracked tiny movements. She developed the Lady’s Glove, which has sensors that let her make music by moving her hands and fingers.

item.title: Pamela Z
item.description: Image source: YouTube @PamelaZ Instrument: BodySynth (1990s) Other musicians use sensors all over different parts of their bodies. Pamela Z has created lots of movement-based instruments, which track different kinds of movements from different parts of the body.

item.title: Imogen Heap
item.description: Image source: Dezeen Instrument: Mi.Mu Gloves (2000s) Imogen Heap is a musician who took the idea of movement-tracking gloves even further. With her Mi.Mu Gloves, she can her control many different parts of the music sheâ€™s playing all at once, and all while playing and singing in front of big audiences.

item.title: Atau Tanaka
item.description: Image source: YouTube @atautana Instrument: Muscle Sensors (2000s) One musician makes sounds with something even simpler than fingers–the muscles in the arms themselves. Atau Tanaka uses special sensors that track not just how he moves his arms but also how he tightens or relaxes his muscles.

item.title: Bjork
item.description: Image source: YouTube, Reactable Legacy Instrument: Reactable, Biophilia app (2000s) Bjork (said like bee-york) used a device called the Reactable, where she placed blocks on a table to control different sounds by moving them around.

item.title: Marco Donnarumma
item.description: Image source: YouTube Instrument: XTH Sense (2010s) A very recent musician is Marco Donnarumma who created an instrument called XTH Sense. His instrument not only tracks how the muscles in his arms move, but also how they sound.
